body: EERILY silent does not begin to describe it. For nearly the entire trip from 42nd Street to Coney Island, the commuters on the evening F train -- a seemingly handpicked cross-section of the city's races, ages, careers and sartorial tendencies -- are soundless. When the train stops between stations and the usual mechanical hum powers down as we wait
title: NEXT STOP; A Month Of Commuting

body: THERE is a well-worn path between New York City and the surrounding suburbs. Over the years, many New Yorkers have made the move, looking for safer streets, better schools, bigger houses and more room to grow. Now another group is making the trek, and the reason is more squarely focused on money. People are discovering that with Manhattan's high
title: Cashing Out

body: In a move that underscores the mayoral aide Daniel L. Doctoroff's continued influence over city development, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Thursday named Robert C. Lieber, a key lieutenant of Mr. Doctoroff's, to succeed him as deputy mayor for economic development. Mr. Doctoroff handpicked Mr. Lieber to run the city's Economic Development
title: Influence of Mayor's Departing Deputy Is Seen in His Successor

body: ALTHOUGH Robyn Sklaren and Brian Fountain's kitchen is spotless, with nice new cabinets and countertops, it has the sad air of neglect. On a recent Sunday morning, no smells of brunch or even boxed doughnuts wafted from the space. ''We're pretty much only good with toast,'' said Ms. Sklaren, 29. It's a fairly big kitchen, flooded with light from a
title: HABITATS; Space To Nurture Obsessions

body: Daniel L. Doctoroff was to have been the Robert Moses of the Bloomberg era, a bold visionary who would guide a sweeping revitalization of New York and put to rest the notion that the age of building big had ended. But now, as Mr. Doctoroff ends his tenure as the longest-serving deputy mayor for economic development, much of his agenda remains
title: Mayor's Big-Thinking Aide Leaves City Hall With Mixed Legacy

body: Correction Appended DUKE RILEY Magnan Projects 317 10th Avenue, near 28th Street Magnan Emrich Contemporary 505 West 28th Street, Chelsea Both through Dec. 22 Last summer, the artist Duke Riley attracted the attention of the Coast Guard, the F.B.I. and countless bloggers when his homemade submarine got too close to the Queen Mary 2 cruise ship in
title: Art in Review

body: The area surrounding Chausseestrasse, a former no man's land where a wall once stood in Berlin, may not seem to invite immediate comparisons with the Red Hook section of Brooklyn. But architects and urban planners see parallels in the rapid growth of both of these formerly gritty neighborhoods, particularly in how the arts have spurred
title: Two Cities Linked By Design

body: Porcelain Diplomacy Starting tomorrow, the Bard Graduate Center will show more than 300 elaborate pieces, many of them for serving tea, chocolate, coffee, sugar and so forth, in an exhibition called ''Fragile Diplomacy: Meissen Porcelain for European Courts,'' which will run through Feb. 11. Meissen has been made in Germany since the early 18th
title: Calendar

body: AND so the migration of the taco eaters begins. The sun has set on the Red Hook ball fields' food vendors for the season, so south and east the pilgrims go, to Fifth Avenue in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, winter feeding ground of the displaced soccer taco enthusiast. The good news is that the stretch from Green-Wood Cemetery south to the Brooklyn-Queens
title: $25 AND UNDER; Following the Tacos South for the Winter

body: MICHAEL ANDALORO lived in Alphabet City for nearly 25 years before moving to Brooklyn last year, and he doesn't long for Manhattan. ''I didn't miss it for the past 10 years,'' Mr. Andaloro said facetiously. The bohemian East Village of his younger days had become so bourgeois that he could barely recognize it. ''On Thursday nights, it was like
title: HABITATS | BEDFORD-STUYVESANT, BROOKLYN; Rediscovering New York As It Used to Be

body: Standard 41, a new furniture showroom in Red Hook, Brooklyn, is run by Andrew Raible, a designer and woodworker, above left, and his father, John, an architect. The pair work out of a loft at the 1860s Red Hook Stores warehouse overlooking Pier 41 (the origin of the showroom's name), where they sell chairs, tables, desks and other furniture made to
title: FURNITURE; In Red Hook, Father and Son Converge and Diverge

body: Moonshine is the kind of cozy, lived-in Brooklyn bar that allowed customers to bring dogs inside and meat for the grill outside, both of which, it would come to learn, are against New York City health department regulations. But no one foresaw one violation uncovered during a recent surprise inspection of the Red Hook tavern. It was tucked within
title: A Corona, Please, And Don't Hold The Lime

body: The robbers carried guns into dark bars in broad daylight on back-to-back Sundays in Red Hook, the ballyhooed next-great-neighborhood of Brooklyn that has stubbornly maintained much of its gritty charm and, with it, danger. News of the first holdup spread quickly: On Sept. 23, shortly after 2 p.m., two men entered Red Hook Bait and Tackle on Van
title: Bartender Snaps a String of Brooklyn Tavern Holdups

title: Calendar

body: Blue Marble Ice Cream in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, has an airy, whitewashed look that suggests the seashore, which somehow enhances a scoop of refreshing mint chip, deeply flavorful strawberry, creamy vanilla or lightly sweetened green tea, above right. Alexis Miesen and Jennie Dundas, the owners, have created a child-friendly place serving
title: Two New Blues in Brooklyn, the Upbeat Kind

At 8 p.m., Bargemusic, Fulton Ferry Landing near the Brooklyn Bridge, Brooklyn, (718) 624-2083, bargemusic.org; $35;

body: JAZZ Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music. MARTIAL SOLAL Martial Solal, who celebrated his 80th birthday six weeks ago, has few peers among jazz pianists. Strictly speaking, probably none. He's a probing modernist with a mercurial touch, but of course there are plenty of those. And he's a virtuoso technician often cited as the
title: Jazz Listings

body: More than 20 elected officials, in an effort to save the embattled cargo-shipping operations on the Red Hook piers in Brooklyn, signed a letter yesterday urging the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to offer a 10-year lease to the cargo terminal's operator. Officials in the Bloomberg administration said in July that they were rethinking
title: METRO BRIEFING | NEW YORK; Brooklyn: Officials Back Cargo Operator

body: Imagine a crisp, tangy apple robed in sumptuous caramel, a candy apple unlike any other you've had. Impossible, you say? This month and next, Baked, a pastry shop in Brooklyn, is making exemplary examples of the genre, using Macoun and Cortland apples from the Greenmarket for now, and other varieties later. The apples are hand-dipped in either
title: Compliments on a Stick: It's Apple-Dipping Season in Brooklyn

body: Can documentaries by independent filmmakers promote global understanding? A $19 million initiative to be announced today by ITVS International, a unit of the federally mandated Independent Television Service, plans to try, by financing work by foreign filmmakers to be shown on American television and by arranging distribution of American-made
title: Initiating a Global Pipeline For Documentaries on TV

body: This should be a moment to savor for the venerable Latin food vendors of the Red Hook soccer fields in Brooklyn. With help from well-placed allies and the passionate advocacy of their media-wise organizer, the vendors -- lately a cause célèbre for pro-immigrant groups, free-market cheerleaders and gastrobloggers alike -- recently won an extension
title: The Food's Still Great, but Success Divides the Vendors

Tomorrow, 1 to 5 p.m., and Sunday, 1 to 9 p.m., staged readings of literary
title: Around Town

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites QUEENS BOTANICAL GARDEN The word sustainable has lately been used to describe everything from toothpaste to sport utility vehicles to cruises. So you can be forgiven for greeting the news that the Queens Botanical Garden is opening a sustainable visitors' center on Friday with a bit of skepticism. After all, wouldn't
title: Spare Times

body: NOVELLA CARPENTER remembers the day she killed her first chicken. It was a rooster named Twitchy who had been injured by an opossum that got into her backyard chicken flock. About to leave for vacation, Ms. Carpenter, 34, had no way of caring for the wounded Twitchy while she was away. So she took it to the back porch and chopped off its head. ''I
title: A Chicken on Every Plot, a Coop in Every Backyard

body: There is an almost eerie quiet as New York City approaches the September 18 primary elections. No federal, statewide, citywide, City Council, or state legislative posts are at issue, making this the least active primary season in recent memory. This has produced a quirky result: The primary's marquee events are three judicial contests in Brooklyn.
title: THE CITY; A Quiet (and Disquieting) Primary

body: In its 15-year history American Stevedoring has moved hundreds of thousands of televisions, loaded tons and tons of coffee and shipped and received everything from sofas to ambulances. Now it is hauling its most precious cargo yet: tenors. A 69-year-old former oil tanker moored in the company's container port in Red Hook, Brooklyn, has been
title: Don't Rock the Boat; Opera in Progress

body: The Department of Parks and Recreation said yesterday that it would extend the temporary permit for the food vendors of Red Hook through Oct. 21, the traditional end of their season. A committee that represents the vendors, who sell Latino snacks each summer weekend in Red Hook Park, has had a series of temporary permits regularly renewed; the
title: METRO BRIEFING | NEW YORK; Brooklyn: Reprieve For Food Vendors

body: Firefighters have very few places they can go to vent, to shed tears or to admit that their job can be overwhelming. One of those places is a small building along the waterfront in Red Hook, Brooklyn, where a group offers counseling and holistic therapy to firefighters and their families. The group, Friends of Firefighters, was established in 2002,
title: Where Firefighters Once Worked, Group Sees a Place to Soothe Their Pain

body: The cavernous studio of the artists Doug and Mike Starn in Red Hook, Brooklyn, has been their source of inspiration since they began working there in 1989.
title: WORKSPACE; Sanctuary of Art

body: IT is not the kind of place you expect to find art, across the street from a sanitation depot and a firehouse at the dead end of Union Street in Red Hook, Brooklyn. But the cavernous studio of the artists Doug and Mike Starn has been their sanctuary and source of inspiration since they began working there in 1989. A former ice-cream-truck garage,
title: WORKSPACE; In the Garage, With Heat, Light and Snowflakes

body: FOR most of August, Diane Hatz has been on a national quest for pie. She has eaten walnut pie in northern California; lemonade peach pie in Laramie, Wyo.; and a pie of goat cheese, onion and tomato in Kansas City, Mo. Yesterday, she and other members of the food-centered educational group Sustainable Table wheeled their bio-fueled rock-star tour
title: On the Road to Farm Aid, The Long, Sweet Way

body: Two years ago Freddy Saint-Aignan and his wife, Angelika, found the perfect location for their fledgling bar/restaurant, the Sugar Lounge: Columbia Street in Brooklyn. The building was just the right size, had a spacious backyard garden and sat beside Upper New York Bay. The city had big plans for the area: green space and parks, cruise ship piers
title: COLUMBIA STREET JOURNAL; Two Years Later, a Street Still Waits For Its Promised Gentrification

body: Joanna Haigood is obsessed with the notion of memory and place, and being the site artist she is, she digs deeper than most to expose their roots. But none of her works have meant as much to her as ''Invisible Wings,'' last performed at Jacob's Pillow in 1998 and being revived this week as part of that dance festival's 75th-anniversary season. The
title: Freedom Bound In Forest Dance

body: THE food, by now, has been well chronicled: Vendors lining the edge of Red Hook Park in Brooklyn on summer weekends sling tacos and pupusas on folding tables under tarpaulin roofs. But for many of the people who flock to the park, they are just a warm-up for the main event, the Technicolor baseball games played all day long against a backdrop of
title: NEW YORK IN FOCUS; The Pastime Nacional

body: Brandon Diaz ran across the springy grass infield, stood atop the pitcher's mound and, with a short windup, let loose with a curveball to his father, John. The hardball zipped through the warm air, landing squarely in his father's glove with a plop that could barely be heard above the raspy hiss and clang from a high-rise under construction across
title: CITYWIDE; On Playing Fields, Grass Is an Endangered Species

body: New York City liquor stores generally tend toward the glum or the precious, involving either hurried exchanges with bulletproof glass and brown bags or bright, sleek shops that look more like U.F.O.'s. LeNell's, a liquor store in Red Hook, has always aimed for a laid-back feel, with its sign out front advertising ''likker,'' and a coming wine
title: RED HOOK JOURNAL; A Neighborhood Fixture Faces an Uncertain Future

title: Dance

body: The scene at the Red Hook piers in Brooklyn on Friday morning was a standoff between grit and glitz. On Pier 10, at Brooklyn's last remaining cargo terminal, longshoremen hoisted freight containers off the backs of flatbed trucks lined up like roller-coaster cars and set them down on the deck of a mammoth freighter. Across an inlet on Pier 12, a
title: Cargo Ships Leaving Red Hook? Maybe Not So Fast

body: At slack tide off Red Hook, Brooklyn, there are usually lots of things floating in the water, most of which you would not want to touch without the help of a good hazmat suit. But just after sunrise yesterday, something truly strange was bobbing there in the shallows near Pier 41: a submarine fashioned almost completely from wood, and inside it a
title: An Artist and His Sub Surrender in Brooklyn

body: Images of Duke Riley's voyage to intercept the Queen Mary II with his replica of a Revolutionary Era-war submarine in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

body: JOE ANASTASIO, a slim, dark-haired Web designer for a Wall Street publishing company, was standing outside Madison Square Garden, dressed in black work boots, a torn blue check shirt and a bomber jacket. It was a brisk Sunday morning in the spring, and among the swirl of tourists clutching maps and hockey fans in Rangers jerseys, he might easily
title: Children of Darkness

title: Jazz

body: The only homeless shelter in New York just for veterans will close in August for renovations, which city officials say will improve conditions there. But the plans are upsetting some of its residents. The shelter, the Borden Avenue Veterans' Residence, in Long Island City, Queens, is to reopen in November with a little more than half its current
title: Renovation At a Shelter Has Residents Feeling Uneasy

title: Spare Times

body: To the Editor: Re ''Study Criticizes Parks Dept. Management'' (news article, June 27): While it is true that people in wealthy neighborhoods often make donations to enhance their local parks, citizens in less well-off areas can also organize to support green space. In fact, the Partnerships for Parks program was created in 1995 by the Parks
title: Support Your Local Park

title: City's Plans For Housing Flop in Albany

body: LAST October, John Deragon began tinkering with a recipe for Abbott's bitters, a cocktail ingredient that has beguiled drinks fanatics for years. Over the next two months, Mr. Deragon, the chief technology officer of Waterfront Media, an online health and wellness company in Brooklyn, tweaked the formula drop by drop, using single-spice infusions
title: A Bit Of History, Reborn In a Glass

body: Looking Ahead BENOIT BISTRO NEW YORK Alain Ducasse has taken over Brasserie LCB (formerly La Côte Basque), which was closed by the Department of Health three months ago and never reopened. Jean-Jacques Rachou, who owned the restaurant, has retired. By March Mr. Ducasse plans to open a classic French bistro-brasserie based on Benoit, one of his
title: Off the Menu

body: DARIO MODON is a burly 64-year-old who stands 6 feet 2 and has painted-on, arched eyebrows and a coy, puckered smile. He marches around the Red Hook projects in Brooklyn, where he lives, with a long More Red cigarette between his fingers. Before retiring, he spent decades working in the fashion industry, designing lingerie and evening wear and
title: THE VOICE; Satin Frocks and Housing Law

author: E-mail: homefront@nytimes.com.
body: UNTIL recently, Sandra Castillo, 37, a laid-off factory worker, had never driven anything larger than a car. But now she was at the wheel of a 30-foot-long school bus. She made a tight right turn from a wide avenue into a narrow side street in Brooklyn as smoothly as a veteran bus driver. At her side, with a dual brake if needed, sat Christopher
title: HOME FRONT; Training for the Twists Of Driving a School Bus

body: On the concrete floor of a garage turned kitchen, behind a curtain stamped in lavender and green, was a freezer as tall as a man, as long as a car and as wide as a love seat. Inside was a pile of cardboard boxes stuffed with lettuce, tomatoes and cactus leaf nopales, a Mexican delicacy. The coolers on the opposite end were packed with raw meat: 40
title: SUMMER RITUALS | TACOS AND HUARACHES; Stuffing Tortillas and Parkgoers, Dawn to Dusk

body: FOR CHILDREN CHESS SERIES (Sunday) The Chess and Checkers House in Central Park has frequently been used for just about everything but chess and checkers -- it's been a visitors' center and a card shop -- but Renée Yarzig, who runs nonprofit chess programs, is trying to return it to its original purpose. At each event in her new Summer Chess
title: Spare Times

body: An article last Thursday about six home kitchens misstated the age for Simone Leigh, an artist whose kitchen is decorated with found objects. She is 39, not 46. The article also misstated the location for Jill's, a restaurant owned by Jill Pettijohn, whose home kitchen was featured. It is in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, not Red Hook.
title: Correction

body: The posting on Craigslist was vague, something about ''set dressing'' and a movie company and a sale. Cash only. But the two words circulating among the Internet cognoscenti, could not have been clearer: ''The Sopranos.'' So it was that nine days after the finale of the HBO mob drama, scores of ''Sopranos'' fans found themselves yesterday in front
title: Seeking a Souvenir of Those Mobsters You Hate to Love

body: 'ADVENTURES NYC' (Tomorrow) Pitching a tent in the backyard isn't an option for most Manhattan children. But tomorrow the Parks and Recreation Department will try to make at least part of the borough seem more like Yellowstone than like the land of the yellow cab. The occasion is the third annual ''Adventures NYC,'' which will turn a wide swath of
title: SPARE TIMES: June 15 - June 21; For Children

body: The mighty Monitor, the ironclad Civil War ship, was built on Greenpoint's gritty waterfront. The Graving Dock at the Todd Shipyards in Red Hook was the terminal for ships traveling from the Erie Canal. The Old Dutch Mustard Company in Williamsburg churned out prepared mustard, vinegars and fruit juice for half a century. The mustard building was
title: Brooklyn Waterfront Called Endangered Site

body: THE American kitchen has been an aspirational space ever since electricity and post-World War I prosperity commingled in a nifty new appliance called the refrigerator. ''There are scads of ads from the 1920s showing people in tuxedos and evening gowns literally adoring their fridge,'' said Victoria Matranga, a historian of industrial design and the
title: Kitchen Tales

body: RED HOOK is one of those rare New York neighborhoods where the stars aren't completely obscured by city lights. By late summer, Gita Nandan and Jens Veneman will be able to track them from their bathtub, which they're preparing to relocate to their back deck. And if the gardening gods are beneficent, they'll be able to reach out of the suds to snag
title: HABITATS/Red Hook, Brooklyn; Why Ask for the Moon If You Have the Stars?

body: In theory, the G train, the lime green line that never enters Manhattan, runs for about 14 miles, from Red Hook, Brooklyn, all the way to Forest Hills, Queens. For residents of Jackson Heights who enjoy the cuisines of Carroll Gardens, for example, or for Greenpointers who shop at the Queens Center mall in Elmhurst, the G can be a straight shot, no
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: QUEENS UP CLOSE; Does the 'G' Stand for Ghost?

body: In the backyard of a renovated house in Red Hook, Brooklyn, a view of the night sky reveals more than just city lights.
title: Home Away in Red Hook

body: Dancing in the Streets' free summer events are not to be missed, especially when they take place in Red Hook, a Brooklyn neighborhood with an appealing mix of industrial grit and big stretches of sky. Tomorrow the organization presents ''Hip Hop Generation Next,'' a joint effort by five Brooklyn youth groups that is led by the veteran dancer
title: The Listings: June 8 - June 14; HIP HOP GENERATION NEXT

body: PUPUSAS, sunburns, soccer: could this be the last summer to get them all at the same place? For years a pan-Latin group of food vendors has assembled each Saturday and Sunday at Bay and Clinton Streets in Brooklyn, drawing fans of street food from all over the city to the Red Hook Recreation Area. The Food Vendors Committee, their umbrella
title: Red Hook Vendors Pressed to Get New Permit

title: SPARE TIMES | JUNE 1 - JUNE 7; For Children

body: On an industrial strip of land hemming Newtown Creek, pipelines snake low to the ground, connecting an array of giant beige oil tanks. From outward appearances, this little patch of Texas in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, would not seem to easily fit into Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan for a greener, less petroleum-dependent future. But this fuel
title: Biodiesel Makers See Opening in City's Green Plans

body: ON warm summer weekends along the Brooklyn waterfront, at the end of Columbia Street, the baseball and soccer fields of Red Hook Park are lined with Latin American food vendors and families spread out on blankets to watch players in crisp whites and vivid primary colors. But looming behind the fields is a spectral counterpoint to that lively scene:
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RED HOOK; For a Rusty Industrial Relic, a Bid for Revival

body: When the Queen Mary 2 made Brooklyn its New York home port, Marty Markowitz, the borough's president and most tireless booster, fairly burst with pride. ''Brooklyn's ship has come in,'' a press release quoted him as saying last year when the ship made its maiden docking at Pier 12 in Red Hook. ''All aboard.'' On Thursday, Mr. Markowitz's own ship
title: To Sell Brooklyn, Borough Leader Took Free Trip On Cruise Ship

body: GARDENING in New York City can require the determination of a weed pushing through a sidewalk. There are hardships of space, light, microclimate and wind, not to mention the pain of hauling supplies across town and, frequently, up several flights of stairs. Add to that the shortage of serious garden centers -- the kind with space for 50-pound bags
title: New York's Nurseries Try a Transplant

body: Police officers pulled two workers from a building that partly collapsed yesterday, police and fire officials said. The workers, whose names were not disclosed by the police, were inside the three-story building, at 51 Woodhull Street in Red Hook, when the second floor collapsed, pushing the first floor into the basement and trapping the workers,
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Two Injured In Collapse

body: Restaurant Sorrel 605 Carlton Avenue (St. Mark's Avenue), Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, (718) 622-1190. Sometimes what seems like a bargain is too good to be true; other times you walk away happy. You can stroll out on either side of the equation with Restaurant Sorrel, where three courses are $25, cash only. (Wines run $7 to $10 a glass.) The man
title: DINING BRIEFS; IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: A lot of the sounds heard over the weekend at the Hook in Red Hook, Brooklyn, came with the force of an assault. There were whipsaw screeches, scorching blasts, solar-plexus-socking rumbles. Also ominous whorls and scabrous wails. It was all part of the fourth annual No Fun Fest, a transnational summit on the state of extreme experimental music,
title: MUSIC REVIEW; Tough Territory in the World of Experimental Music

title: The Listings: May 18 - May 24

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites PARK SLOPE HOUSE TOUR New York's housing bubble may never burst, but there is one way to temper -- or, depending on your rental status, inflame -- your real-estate envy. title: Spare Times

body: Imagine, if you will, that you are Niko Bellic, the main character of Grand Theft Auto IV, a video game due out in October. With free rein in Liberty City, a meticulously rendered stand-in for New York, you can carjack a hot rod in Dumbo and zoom down the Manhattan Bridge at 140 miles per hour. If you're short on cash, you can mug a tourist in
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: STATEN ISLAND UP CLOSE; No Muggings in New Dorp, And Game Fans Are Miffed

body: Selective listings by critics of The New York Times of new and noteworthy cultural events in the New York metropolitan region this week. * denotes a highly recommended film, concert, show or exhibition. Theater Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional
title: The Listings: May 11 - May 17

body: Around Town Museums and Sites MERCHANT'S HOUSE MUSEUM, 29 East Fourth Street, East Village. Sunday at 1:30 and 3 p.m., ''Annual Mother's Day Tea,'' with finger sandwiches and other delicacies, followed by a tour of the museum; $50 per couple, $40 for members (each additional guest, $20). Reservations required: (212) 777-1089. Free. Hours: Thursdays
title: SPARE TIMES: May 11 - May 17

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY Central Park West and 79th Street. Through May 28, ''The Butterfly Conservatory: Tropical Butterflies Alive in Winter,'' a display with hundreds of butterflies in a re-creation of their natural habitat. Through Aug. 19, ''Gold,'' with coins, jewelry and other artifacts. Through April
title: Spare Times

body: IF there is a song of the lazy, unmarried man in New York, the words and music can be found most often in that pile of yellowed and stained takeout menus on top of his fridge. Pummeled after a day of work and bound to the couch by a ''Seinfeld'' mini-marathon on TBS, this man does not venture into the world's most food-diverse city in search of
title: URBAN TACTICS; In Praise of General Tso

body: ''IT'S a law of nature: When the eyes are wet, the animal is alive,'' said Chris Green, stroking the head of a wooden deer. Most of the deer, which he built out of odd parts, looks rather abstract. The body is hollow, its form outlined with folding rulers and rigged with a faucet and other hardware to suggest the animal's own plumbing. The ears are
title: ART; Giving Life to Found Objects, Two by Two

body: THE Manhattan is back. Not back in fashion, I mean. That story is at least a decade old, and even then it wasn't much of a story. Unlike many other cocktails that have recently been roused from long hibernation, the Manhattan never really slumbered, having been kept drowsily awake through the lean years of cocktaildom by French-cuffed businessmen
title: SHAKEN AND STIRRED; The Real Manhattan

body: Drawings From Palisades, Scenes From the Life of Charon Kentler International Drawing Space 353 Van Brunt Street, Red Hook, Brooklyn Through May 6 Elaine Smollin's works on paper sound great on paper. She makes multipanel charcoal drawings on thick watercolor fiber. She creates the charcoal herself from cherry, elm, willow and birch trees near her
title: Art in Review; Elaine Smollin

body: NATURE is so in. Scoff, if you must, as you flip through the May issue of Vogue, which extols the eco-friendly attributes of Cheap Monday jeans. (The label, that two-inch bit of posterior branding, is made from recycled paper.) Roll your eyes at the Sundance Channel's environmental living series, which includes an episode heralding the green
title: If There's A Buck In It Somewhere

body: To reverse the flow of younger people leaving Staten Island, the borough should entice developers to build more affordable apartments close to the ferry, according to a study released yesterday. The St. George neighborhood near the ferry to Manhattan is the closest thing to a downtown district in the borough, but it lacks the vibrancy of other
title: Staten Island Considers New Plans To Keep Its Youth From Leaving

body: Health experts, environmental advocates and politicians called on the federal Environmental Protection Agency yesterday to address contamination and medical problems in Brooklyn and other areas outside Lower Manhattan resulting from the Sept. 11 attack. Speaking at a Congressional hearing held in Brooklyn Borough Hall, they said that with the
title: E.P.A. Is Urged to Widen Focus on 9/11 Health Effects

body: IN the last year, two mega-grocery stores have opened in communities that were previously making do without one: Fairway Market in Red Hook, Brooklyn, and Whole Foods Market at the nexus of a few under-grocered downtown neighborhoods: the East Village, the Lower East Side and NoLIta. Both offer dining options to entice shoppers and the
title: $25 AND UNDER; Two New Markets, With Food to Stay

body: AS Jonathan Lethem made clear so cleverly in his purposely plagiarized article, ''The Ecstasy of Influence,'' in the February Harper's, no canvas is ever really blank. And artists are cut from the same cloth, the tapestry of art history. Even so, to many artists this cloth is somewhat itchy. Why else do so many of them scoff at tradition and march
title: POSSESSED; Chained to His Desk

author: E-mail: eating@nytimes.com
body: ''The Dinner Party,'' Judy Chicago's landmark multimedia installation celebrating the role of women in Western civilization, has moved to a permanent home in the new Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art at the Brooklyn Museum. The work features a table with 39 place settings, each representing a woman in history. Smaller parties can be
title: GOOD EATING/BROOKLYN MUSEUM; Places at the Table

body: The Burgundies of 2004 A tasting of 10 top-flight Burgundies from the 2004 vintage will be held this evening from 6:30 to 8:30 p.m. by the New York Wine Guild, a wine society, at 269 11th Avenue (27th Street). The tasting will be led by Patrick Cappiello of Veritas restaurant. For tickets, $110: newyorkwineguild.com. Wine Basics Best Cellars, an
title: CALENDAR

author: Sarah Shey is the author of ''Sky All Around'' and ''Blue Lake Days,'' children's books set in Iowa.
body: IN my native Iowa, it was easy to be seduced by the pristine geometry of vacant blacktops, where a car can travel at least mile a minute, stair-stepping from field to unclothed field and not meet a patrol car. It was a far cry from New York. The little I had driven in the city, the car in front of me was in control. It appeared obvious that for a
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; Her Ride To Nowhere

body: LIKE a red-faced college student begging his mother not to show visitors the embarrassing old family photos, General Motors would like you to forget its early attempts at car-based crossover utility vehicles. Imagine the company wincing on the sofa as you chuckle your way through G.M.'s picture albums from the '90s, filled with snapshots of the
title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2007 GMC Acadia and Saturn Outlook; G.M. Makes a Grand Entrance, at Last, to the Crossover Ball

body: RED HOOK, a nub of a Brooklyn peninsula jutting into the Buttermilk Channel opposite Governors Island, is perhaps not everyone's ideal place to live. A high-crime area not very long ago, it is at times eerily silent, at others mournfully full of the noise of industry. Broken glass and cracked sidewalks can still be found; amenities, while on the
title: LIVING IN/Red Hook, Brooklyn; Where Tugboats Chug and Ikea's Coming

body: I LIVE in Vladimir V. Putin's hometown, not far from the palaces of the czars, but on a windowsill in my apartment, I have a phone that lives in Brooklyn. It makes and receives calls on the borough's area code as surely as a phone in a takeout joint on Flatbush Avenue, never letting on that it is 4,500 miles away from its supposed stomping ground.
title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Seven One Eight; To Reach Me in Russia, Just Dial Brooklyn

body: For Pat Russo, the corner of the Sunset Park Recreation Center where he founded a free boxing program two decades ago is haunted by the sounds of youthful ambition: the shuffle of fast-moving feet, the grunts of landed punches, the shouts of ''Jab, jab!'' by hawk-eyed coaches. Today the ring is gone, the corner mostly silent. Once offered as an
title: Where Friendly Punches Flew in Brooklyn, Clubs Lose to Rising Rents

author: E-mail: streetlevel@nytimes.com
body: SHOPPING at the Fairway Market on the Upper West Side can be nearly as overwhelming a literary experience as a gustatory one. In every corner of the store, which sits under a blue awning on Broadway and 74th Street, hang signs, densely worded and brimming with enthusiasm, extolling fresh herbs -- ''our little secret'' -- or olive oil, or clam
title: STREET LEVEL / UPPER WEST SIDE; Praise For Foie Gras Fortifies Its Critics

body: WHEN the Queen Mary II docks in Red Hook, Brooklyn, as it will about 30 times this year, passengers will set foot (though perhaps only briefly) in a neighborhood that has been thoroughly dissected by local writers who chronicle every nano-step of its gentrification as if it were front-page news. But to an outsider, Red Hook still feels like a
title: WEEKEND IN NEW YORK | Red Hook; A Potted Palm Grows in Brooklyn

author: E-mail: fyi@nytimes.com
body: Holding Back the Hudson Q. For two years, while driving up the Henry Hudson Parkway, I have noticed at least one and often two huge barges anchored in the river, off about 100th to 120th Streets, attended by a tugboat. What is going on? A. What's going on, according to the Coast Guard, is a long-term job to repair seawalls. Workers are reinforcing
title: F. Y. I.

body: A report last Sunday, about the marriage of Heather Tressel Frank and Todd Kekoa Olsen, misidentified the residence of the bride's parents, Nancy Tressel Frank and Irwin Frank. They live in Red Hook, N.Y., not Brooklyn.
title: Correction

body: Van Brunt Street in Red Hook isn't exactly welcoming. But a young sculptor is lending patinated sparkle to this sleepy shopping strip with the rarefied antiques and jewelry store Erie Basin. Russell Whitmore, a 26-year-old Chicago transplant, chose the location, isolated by the roaring Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, precisely for its quiet remoteness.
title: The Remix; Hidden Treasures

body: TWO years ago, LeNell Smothers and Benjamin Peikes paid $360,000 for their three-story wood-frame house in Red Hook, Brooklyn. Having looked at many scary houses for sale, like the one with the crawl space full of crack vials, a dog slurping water from a rain gutter through a broken window and a deranged cat pacing in the hallway, they felt
title: HABITATS/Red Hook, Brooklyn; Nothing a Shot of Bourbon Won't Cure

body: Heather Tressel Frank, the daughter of Nancy Tressel Frank and Irwin Frank of Brooklyn, was married last evening to Todd Kekoa Olsen, the son of Marcia Olsen of Colorado Springs and Alexander Kaleolani Olsen of Olympia, Wash. The Rev. George Herzog, an interfaith minister, officiated at the New Leaf Café in Manhattan. Mrs. Frank-Olsen, 30, is a
title: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; Heather Frank, Todd Olsen

body: At 14, Rocky Harris knows the routine: You raise your hands high, you keep your mouth shut and you don't dare move a muscle. Then the police officer's gloved hands go up and down each leg, around your waist, across your chest and back, then down your shoulders to your wrists. When they don't find guns or drugs, Rocky said, they let you go. He said
title: As Officers Stop and Frisk, Residents Raise Their Guard

body: Few shows force you to rethink an urban legend. That's the challenge posed by ''Robert Moses and the Modern City,'' a sweeping, scholarly exhibition that breathes fresh air into one of the most tired, overworked and misunderstood subjects in the city's history. Shown at three New York locations, the exhibition traces Moses' remarkable career as
title: EXHIBITION REVIEW; Complex, Contradictory Robert Moses

body: FOR three decades his image has been frozen in time. The bulldozing bully who callously displaced thousands of New Yorkers in the name of urban renewal. The public-works kingpin who championed highways as he starved mass transit. And yes, the visionary idealist who gave New York Lincoln Center and Jones Beach, along with parks, roads, playgrounds
title: ARCHITECTURE; Rehabilitating Robert Moses

body: 'ADVENTURES FROM EZRA JACK KEATS: APT. 3 AND MAGGIE AND THE PIRATE' (Tomorrow and Sunday) Two books by this author and illustrator come to life onstage in the winter musical from Tada!, the youth theater troupe. ''Apt. 3'' focuses on the friendship two children forge with a blind neighbor; ''Maggie and the Pirate'' is about, well, a girl and a
title: Spare Times: Jan 26-Feb. 1; For Children

author: Anthony J. Sebok and Samuel K. Murumba are professors at Brooklyn Law School.
body: WHEN Domino's announced its Brooklyn Style Pizza, New York City had a predictable response. This newspaper ran a story comparing Domino's mass-produced creation with the legendary coal-oven pies made by Totonno's in Coney Island. Food blogs were filled with indignant commentary about what makes a real Brooklyn pizza. At Brooklyn Law School, our
title: Mythic Pizza

body: Erie Basin, a new home furnishings and jewelry store in the Red Hook neighborhood of Brooklyn, carries a carefully chosen selection of objects from the darker side of chic: Marilyn Manson meets ''The Raven.'' Russell Whitmore, the owner, above, favors the old -- like Piero Fornasetti's 1950s fish plates, top left ($900 for a set of three) -- but he
title: CURRENTS: FURNISHINGS; Accents for the Home, Brushed With Darkness
